message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The blood-tinged fluid draining from both nostrils and the description of a clear ring of fluid surrounding blood on a gauze suggest that the patient has a basilar skull fracture with cerebrospinal fluid leak. Bilateral periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes) is a classic sign of basilar skull fracture. Cranial nerve XII palsy and numbness of upper cheek area are less commonly associated with basilar skull fracture. Retroauricular ecchymosis is associated with a mastoid fracture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The blood-tinged fluid draining from the nostrils is suggestive of a basal skull fracture, which is associated with raccoon eyes (bilateral periorbital ecchymosis). Cranial nerve XII palsy, numbness of upper cheek area, and retroauricular ecchymosis are associated with other types of skull fractures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of blood-tinged fluid draining from both nostrils suggests a basal skull fracture, which can lead to bilateral periorbital ecchymosis (also known as “raccoon eyes”) due to blood collecting in the soft tissues around the eyes. Cranial nerve XII palsy and numbness of the upper cheek area are not associated with basal skull fractures, and retroauricular ecchymosis (also known as “Battle’s sign”) is more commonly seen with fractures involving the temporal bone.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The blood-tinged fluid spontaneously draining from both nostrils, especially with a clear ring of fluid surrounding blood, is suggestive of raccoon eyes or bilateral periorbital ecchymosis. This can be caused by a skull base fracture or other head injury. Cranial nerve XII palsy would result in tongue deviation, not relevant to the symptoms presented. Numbness of upper cheek area is suggestive of a trigeminal nerve injury, which is not consistent with the presented symptoms. Retroauricular ecchymosis is suggestive of a basilar skull fracture, but this is not consistent with the presented symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The blood-tinged fluid draining from the nostrils indicates a basilar skull fracture with a cerebrospinal fluid leak. Bilateral periorbital ecchymosis, also known as raccoon eyes, is a common sign of basilar skull fracture. The other options are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a basilar skull fracture, especially with the CSF leakage from the nose. Among the options, bilateral periorbital ecchymosis (also known as raccoon eyes) is a common sign of basilar skull fracture, while the other options are not typically associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The blood-tinged fluid draining from both nostrils and the clear ring of fluid surrounding blood on the gauze suggests a basilar skull fracture. Bilateral periorbital ecchymosis, also known as raccoon eyes, is a classic sign of basilar skull fracture. None of the other options are associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The blood-tinged fluid and the expanding clear ring of fluid suggest CSF rhinorrhea. Bilateral periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes) is a common sign of basilar skull fracture which can be associated with CSF rhinorrhea. Cranial nerve XII palsy can also be a sign of basilar skull fracture but it’s less likely for this patient. Numbness of upper cheek area and retroauricular ecchymosis are not typically associated with basilar skull fracture or CSF rhinorrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The blood-tinged fluid draining from the nose indicates a possible basilar skull fracture. The clear ring of fluid surrounding blood on the gauze is called a halo sign which is indicative of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leakage. Bilateral periorbital ecchymosis (also known as raccoon eyes) is a classic finding in basilar skull fractures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The blood-tinged fluid draining from the patient’s nostrils is indicative of a skull fracture, which is commonly associated with bilateral periorbital ecchymosis. Cranial nerve XII palsy and numbness of upper cheek area are not associated with skull fractures. Retroauricular ecchymosis is a sign of basilar skull fracture, which is not indicated in this case.
